title: Insights from Collin Morikawa’s Victory at ZOZO Championship
text:
Golf is one of the sports that people are struggling to be better. People would love to know how to be like PGA tour players, what they need to work on, and what the nearest way to be a great player is.
Imagine, for a moment, standing on the green, visualizing each swing with the precision of a grandmaster, just like Collin Morikawa did at the illustrious ZOZO Championship in Chiba, Japan. This tournament, born in 2019, he is a Chinese-Japanese American so his last name is from Japan. It was a special tournament for him because he and his ancestors are related to Japan.
In this blog, we will dive into Morikawa’s winning formula and discover what it takes to become a champion on the greens.
Golf is a sport where victory isn’t hurried, where triumph unfolds over days, not minutes. It is unlike the fast-paced courts of basketball or volleyball and demands endurance and laser focus. It’s a game that rewards those who master the art of patience and concentration.
Look at a leaderboard for the tournament and already, you can see the hint of why Morikawa became a champion.


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
✔ ggplot2   3.4.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(gt)
library(wehoop)

avgscore<-read_csv("~/OneDrive - University of Nebraska-Lincoln/Fall 2023/SPMC350 Fall2023/Blog/PGA STATS/Avgscore.csv")


Rows: 77 Columns: 12
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (1): PLAYER
dbl (11): RANK, MOVEMENT, PLAYER_ID, AVG, TOTAL STROKES, TOTAL ADJUSTMENT, T...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
avgscore<-head(avgscore,10)

topavgscore <-avgscore|>select(RANK,PLAYER,R1,R2,R3,R4,`TOTAL STROKES`) 

topavgscore |> 
  gt() |> 
tab_header(
    title = "Is the final round important to be a champion?",
    subtitle = "Morikawa has the best final round in top 10 players."
  ) |> 
    tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Miu Takahashi  |  **Source:** PGAStats")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=13)
     )
   ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#D3D3D3")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      columns = R4
    )
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#FF0000")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      columns = R4,
      rows = R4 == 63
    )
  ) 






  
    
      Is the final round important to be a champion?
    
    
      Morikawa has the best final round in top 10 players.
    
    
      RANK
      PLAYER
      R1
      R2
      R3
      R4
      TOTAL STROKES

    4

72
71
65

Kensei Hirata

    6
Ryo Hisatsune

    6

Emiliano Grillo

      By: Miu Takahashi  |  Source: PGAStats
    
  
  




As you see, he had the best round which marked 63, and he was the player who had the lowest score for the final round in the top 10 players.
Also, take a closer look at the top 10 contenders. Most of the players who finished in the top 10 played better than the third round on the last day. From the table, we can understand that you need to finish strong and play hard til the end if you want to win.
Now, let’s get into more detail. What’s the secret sauce behind those jaw-dropping scores? Of course, they need to make many birdies. However, in the PGA tour, all the players have the ability to get birdies. It’s a skill honed to precision. Then, what sets the champions from those who fall short, despite their birdie prowess?


Code
library(tidyverse)

btb <- read_csv("~/OneDrive - University of Nebraska-Lincoln/Fall 2023/SPMC350 Fall2023/Blog/PGA STATS/Birdie to Bogey ratio.csv")

btb<-head(btb,10)

nbtb <- btb |> 
  select(PLAYER,`TOTAL BIRDIES AND BETTER`,`TOTAL BOGEYS AND WORSE`) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols=-PLAYER, 
    names_to = "Score",
    values_to = "Total"
  )

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=nbtb, aes(x=reorder(PLAYER, Total), weight=Total, fill=Score)) + 
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Count", 
    title="Birdie and Bogey Ratio", 
    subtitle="Morikawa excels in birdies and minimizes bogeys, a top-tier player.", 
    caption="Source: PGA Stats| By Miu Takahashi"
    ) +
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("green", "yellow")) + 
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20,face = "bold"),
       axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10) )





From this data, Morikawa has the most amount of birdies and also fewer bogeys compared with other players. It is important to make fewer mistakes and avoid the worst case in order to beat all players.
Let’s change the angle. Easy question. What do you need to make birdie? It boils down to two essential moves - nailing that approach onto the green, then sinking the putt.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)

Putt <- read_csv("~/OneDrive - University of Nebraska-Lincoln/Fall 2023/SPMC350 Fall2023/Blog/PGA STATS/Putt.csv")


Rows: 77 Columns: 8
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): PLAYER, BIRDIE CONVERSION
dbl (6): RANK, MOVEMENT, PLAYER_ID, AVG, GIR PUTTS, GREENS HIT

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
CMPutt <- Putt |>
  filter(PLAYER == "Collin Morikawa")

EC <- Putt |>
  filter(PLAYER == "Eric Cole")

BH <- Putt |>
  filter(PLAYER == "Beau Hossler")

RI <- Putt |>
  filter(PLAYER == "Ryo Ishikawa")

RS <- Putt |>
  filter(PLAYER == "Robby Shelton")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=Putt, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`), color = "grey") +
    geom_point(
    data=EC, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`), color = "blue")+
   geom_point(
    data=RI, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`), color = "blue")+
   geom_point(
    data=BH, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`), color = "blue")+
   geom_point(
    data=RS, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`), color = "blue")+
  geom_point(
    data=CMPutt, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`), color ="red") +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=CMPutt, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`, label=PLAYER))+
   
 labs(
    x="Average Putt", 
    y="Greens Hit", 
    title="Average Putt",
    subtitle="Navigating the Greens: Decoding the Winning Formula for PGA Triumph", 
    caption="Source: PGA Stats| By Miu Takahashi"
    ) +
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20,face = "bold"),
       axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10) )





Morikawa’s greens hit number is 53 which ranked third and the average putting is 1.604 which ranked second. Blue dots are the stats for the top 5 players. They are located left top which means they also have the top level of green hits and average putt.
In Morikawa’s arsenal, precision reigns supreme. With a greens hit count of 53, he claims the bronze, showcasing his mastery of the approach game. Not to be outdone, his putting average of 1.604 secures him the silver medal in this crucial department. Blue dots are the stats for the top 5 players. They are located left top which means they also have the top level of green hits and average putt.

title: Hello
text: Hello. My name is Miu. I am a student-athlelte at the University of Nebraska. I’m on the womens golf team, majoring in Sports Media and Communication, minoring in Communication. My hometown is Nasu in Japan.

title: Insights from Collin Morikawa’s Victory at ZOZO Championship
text:
Golf is one of the sports in which people strive to improve. Many individuals would love to know how to emulate PGA tour players, what aspects they need to work on, and the most efficient way to become a great player.
Imagine, for a moment, standing on the green, visualizing each swing with the precision of a grandmaster, just like Collin Morikawa did at the illustrious ZOZO Championship in Chiba, Japan. This tournament, born in 2019, holds special significance for him as a Chinese-Japanese American, with his last name originating from Japan. It was a memorable event for him and his ancestors due to their connection to Japan.
In this blog, we will delve into Morikawa’s winning formula and explore what it takes to become a champion, according to the statistical data from the PGA Tour website.
Golf is a sport where victory isn’t rushed; triumph unfolds over days, not minutes. It is unlike the fast-paced courts of basketball or volleyball and demands endurance and laser focus. It’s a game that rewards those who master the art of patience and concentration.
Looking at the leaderboard for the tournament, you can already see the hint of why Morikawa became a champion.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(wehoop)

avgscore<-read_csv("~/OneDrive - University of Nebraska-Lincoln/Fall 2023/SPMC350 Fall2023/Blog/PGA STATS/Avgscore.csv")

avgscore<-head(avgscore,10)

topavgscore <-avgscore|>select(RANK,PLAYER,R1,R2,R3,R4,`TOTAL STROKES`) 

topavgscore |> 
  gt() |> 
tab_header(
    title = "Is the final round important to be a champion?",
    subtitle = "Morikawa has the best final round in top 10 players."
  ) |> 
    tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Miu Takahashi  |  **Source:** PGATour Stats")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=13)
     )
   ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#D3D3D3")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      columns = R4
    )
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#FF0000")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      columns = R4,
      rows = R4 == 63
    )
  )

As you can see, he had the best round, marked at 63, and he was the player with the lowest score for the final round among the top 10 players.
Also, take a closer look at the top 10 contenders. Most of the players who finished in the top 10 played better than they did in the third round on the last day. From the table, we can understand that you need to finish strong and play hard until the end if you want to win.
Now, let’s get into more detail. What’s the secret sauce behind those jaw-dropping scores? Of course, they need to make many birdies. However, in the PGA tour, all the players have the ability to get birdies. It’s a skill honed to precision. Then, what sets the champions apart from those who fall short, despite their birdie prowess?


Code
library(tidyverse)

btb <- read_csv("~/OneDrive - University of Nebraska-Lincoln/Fall 2023/SPMC350 Fall2023/Blog/PGA STATS/Birdie to Bogey ratio.csv")

btb<-head(btb,10)

nbtb <- btb |> 
  select(PLAYER,`TOTAL BIRDIES AND BETTER`,`TOTAL BOGEYS AND WORSE`) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols=-PLAYER, 
    names_to = "Score",
    values_to = "Total"
  )

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=nbtb, aes(x=reorder(PLAYER, Total), weight=Total, fill=Score)) + 
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Count", 
    title="Offense or Defense: What's More Crucial?", 
    subtitle="Morikawa excels in birdies and minimizes bogeys, a top-tier player.", 
    caption="Source: PGATour Stats| By Miu Takahashi"
    ) +
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("red", "blue")) + 
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20,face = "bold"),
       axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10) )





From this data, Morikawa has the most number of birdies and also fewer bogeys compared to other players. It is important to make fewer mistakes and avoid the worst-case scenario in order to beat all players.
Let’s change the angle. Here’s an easy question: What do you need to make a birdie? It boils down to two essential moves—nailing that approach onto the green and then sinking the putt.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)

Putt <- read_csv("~/OneDrive - University of Nebraska-Lincoln/Fall 2023/SPMC350 Fall2023/Blog/PGA STATS/Putt.csv")

CMPutt <- Putt |>
  filter(PLAYER == "Collin Morikawa")

EC <- Putt |>
  filter(PLAYER == "Eric Cole")

BH <- Putt |>
  filter(PLAYER == "Beau Hossler")

RI <- Putt |>
  filter(PLAYER == "Ryo Ishikawa")

RS <- Putt |>
  filter(PLAYER == "Robby Shelton")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=Putt, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`), color = "grey") +
    geom_point(
    data=EC, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`), color = "blue")+
   geom_point(
    data=RI, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`), color = "blue")+
   geom_point(
    data=BH, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`), color = "blue")+
   geom_point(
    data=RS, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`), color = "blue")+
  geom_point(
    data=CMPutt, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`), color ="red") +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=CMPutt, 
    aes(x=`AVG`, y=`GREENS HIT`, label=PLAYER))+
 labs(
    x="Average Putt", 
    y="Greens Hit", 
    title="Crack PGA's Winning Formula with Greens",
    subtitle="Morikawa has the top level of greens regulations and average putting.", 
    caption="Source: PGATour Stats| By Miu Takahashi"
    ) +
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20,face = "bold"),
       axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10) )





Morikawa’s greens hit number is 53, which ranks third, and his average putting is 1.604, ranking second. The blue dots represent the stats for the top 5 players, located in the left top corner, indicating that they also have the top level of green hits and average putt.
There are numerous aspects to winning and becoming a PGA Tour champion, but we can pinpoint the skills that are particularly important.
